pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [3ab1253fec](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17000/commits/3ab1253fec8b3ac4f038575f3eb5bf3b5b388248)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.Fermat`|674|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ coprime_fermat_fermat`
`+ fermat`
`+ fermat_eq_prod_add_two`
`+ fermat_one`
`+ fermat_product`
`+ fermat_two`
`+ fermat_zero`
`+ odd_fermat`
`+ strictMono_fermat`
`+ two_lt_fermat`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
What is the relation of this PR with #14874?

> What is the relation of this PR with #14874?

I was not aware of that, but the results are different. 
Happy to rebase is either way. I think for #14874 it would be good if they used the terminology introduced here.
Congrats on getting number 17,000! Here's some initial remarks.

Since these are pretty trivial lemmas I think it's fine to have them grouped together like this:
```suggestion
@[simp] theorem fermat_zero : fermat 0 = 3 := rfl
@[simp] theorem fermat_one : fermat 1 = 5 := rfl
@[simp] theorem fermat_two : fermat 2 = 17 := rfl
```

```suggestion
## Main theorems

- `coprime_fermat_fermat`: two distinct fermat numbers are coprime.
-/

open Nat
```

a) Does this make sense as a `simp` lemma? I can't imagine you're going to come across the LHS much, even within this file.
b) I'd imagine `fermat_eq_prod_add_two` is the more useful lemma, since it avoids natural subtraction (and it's the one you use for `coprime_fermat_fermat`).

a) not super sure, but it seems to be a somewhat simple lhs. For the next lemma in this file, we could use this simp. But I'm happy to remove it if you think
b) yeah, since I use `fermat_product` in the proof anyhow, I thought I might as well give it a name.

I hadn't ever heard of this name for this theorem, and Google seems to have the same opinion - every single result I'm finding is for Goldbach's conjecture instead. Is this name used in any literature?

it is mentioned in wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermat_number
and here
https://proofwiki.org/wiki/Goldbach%27s_Theorem
A search for "Goldbach's theorem" fermat numbers also give many books
Is this a more useful statement than `3  fermat n`?

I think both are equally useful, but having both seems like an overkill. I added this one, because I though `fermat n - 2` might appear in more than one theorem on fermat numbers and this way, one can easily remove the nat subtraction, but of course it would also be easy to do that if three_le_fermat was present.

```suggestion
theorem fermat_eq_prod_add_two {n : } : fermat n = ( k in Finset.range n, fermat k) + 2 := by
```

pullRequest.title: feat(NumberTheory/Fermat): Fermat numbers
